sub_title: Associate Professor, Debye Institute for Nanomaterials Science and Chemistry Department, Utrecht University
summary:
I work on the modeling of the structural, electronic, magnetic and quantum electron transport properties of nanomaterials using first-principles computational techniques as Density Functional Theory (DFT) and Non-Equilibrium Green’s Function (NEGF). 
The results of my research activity have been published in journals of high impact factor (IF) as Nano Letters, ACSnano, Phys Rev Lett... 
The investigated systems range from Carbon Nanotubes (CNTs), monatomic C chains, BN nanoribbons, III-V semiconductor nanowires, multiferroic materials. 
These investigations have lead to a deep understanding of the fundamental physical properties of one-dimensional systems that, in turn, is essential to design new nanoelectronic and spintronic devices and/or improve their performances. For this reason, these works are often conducted in direct collaboration with experimentalists.
For instance, I have investigated a number of functionalization schemes of CNTs in order to achieve selective detection of various gas molecules. I have employed NEGF and DFT to predict spin-polarized electron transport in monatomic C chains connected to graphene nanoribbons, hence simulating the behavior of all-C nanoelectronic devices. 
I have experience also in using beyond-DFT techniques as the GW approximation. I have used GW to compute the band-gap of the wurtzite polymorph of InAs and GaAs in order to explain photoluminescence measurements (performed by myself) on III-V NWs. Recently, I've performed further modelling of III-V NWs to identify the optimal conditions to grow straight InAs–on–GaAs NW heterostructures. Presently, I'm modelling magnetic multiferroic superlattices, aiming at applications as spintronic devices and, in particular, magnetically readable and electrically writable random access memories (M-RAM).

Specialties: ab initio calculations, nanoscale device modelling, nanoelectronic, spintronic, electrical and optical characterication at the nano- and micro-scale, clean room fabrication.
